greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Weight array W={w(i,j)} of the natural number array A000027.
comment: The lattice lines in the first quadrant (including the x and y axes) cut the plane into unit squares.  Suppose a weight w(i,j) is assigned to the square that has as upper right corner the point (i,j).  Let s(m,n) be the sum of the weights w(i,j) for 1<=i<=m, 1<=j<=n.  We call the array W={w(i,j)} the weight array of the array S={s(m,n)} and S the accumulation array of W.  For the case at hand, S is the array of natural numbers having the following antidiagonals: (1), then (2,3), then (4,5,6), then (7,8,9,10) and so on.
In general, the weight array W of an arbitrary rectangular array S={s(i,j): i>=1, j>=1} is defined in two steps:
(1) extend s by defining s(i,j)=0 if i=0 or j=0;
formula: row n: n followed by A000012, for n>1.
example: so that the accumulation array has corner
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_, Sep 11 2008
